I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
A.  Justification 
1.  Introduction. The proposed transaction technical assistance (TA) facility will provide 
project preparation and capacity building support to three ensuing projects, comprising (i) Yunnan 
Lincang Border Economic Cooperation Zone Infrastructure Comprehensive Development Project, 
(ii) multitranche financing facility (MFF) and Tranche 1 for Xinjiang Regional Cooperation and 
Integration Promotion Investment Program, and (iii) MFF and Tranche 1 for Inner Mongolia 
Regional Cooperation and Integration Promotion Investment Program. The ensuing projects will 
support the efforts of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) toward stronger participation in 
regional cooperation and integration (RCI), notably the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) and 
the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) programs. The transaction TA is listed 
in the country operations business plan 2017–2019 for the PRC.1 
 
2.   Government’s Strategy. RCI is an important part of the PRC’s national development 
strategies. The Thirteenth Five Year Plan (FYP) for National Economic and Social Development 
which covers the period of 2016–2020 committed the PRC to “break new grounds for opening up, 
build mutual trust with partners, promote investment and trade cooperation, enhance people-to-
people exchanges, and achieve win-win results through deepening of regional cooperation and 
integration”.2 The Thirteenth FYP attaches special importance to development and opening-up of 
the border areas, particularly Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region (GZAR), Inner Mongolia 
Autonomous Region (IMAR), Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region (XUAR), and Yunnan Province. 
According to the Plan, GZAR will serve as the gateway to the Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations; Yunnan will build itself into the PRC’s center for pivoting to South and Southeast Asia; 
XUAR will become the PRC’s window for opening-up to Central and West Asia; and IMAR will be 
a hub for cooperation with Mongolia and the broader Northeast Asia region (footnote 2).  The four 
border provinces are also active participants of the Asian Development Bank (ADB)-coordinated 
RCI initiatives—GZAR and Yunnan are part of the GMS program, and IMAR and XUAR are 
members of the CAREC program, and they have also mainstreamed RCI into their respective 
development strategies, notably their provincial-level Thirteenth FYP.  
 
3.  ADB strategy and performance. RCI is a prominent theme and a core area of operations 
of ADB's Long-Term Strategic Framework, or Strategy 2020 and its Midterm Review. In line with 
this strategic framework, ADB will increase its RCI-related assistance to at least 30% of its total 
operations by 2020. ADB’s new Operational Plan for RCI puts special emphasis on promoting 
connectivity,  competitiveness,  and  regional  public  goods.3 RCI  is  an  integral  part  of  ADB 
operations in the PRC. All the country partnership strategy (CPS) documents since 2004 have 
highlighted the importance of RCI for the PRC, especially for development of its border provinces. 
RCI was one of the five strategic priorities of the CPS 2016–2020 for the PRC.4 For the current 
CPS period, the regional orientation of the country program has been further strengthened to 
complement ADB’s support for the CAREC and GMS programs. ADB works closely with the 
government to support RCI through country projects and TA. As of 31 December 2016, ADB’s 
lending to the PRC in support of the GMS and CAREC programs comprised 27 projects totaling

$4.45  billion,  focusing  on  transport  (road,  railway,  and  port)  networks,  infrastructure  and 
environment  improvement  in  border  and  corridor  cities/towns,  border  economic  zone 
development, improvement of border crossing points, and development of small and medium-
sized enterprises in border areas of the provinces and autonomous regions involved in regional 
cooperation. During the period of 2017–2019, six investment projects are planned under the broad 
framework of GMS and CAREC.5 These projects will help further enhance the PRC's physical 
connectivity and trade and investment links with its neighboring countries and support economic 
corridor development. 
 
4.  In 2016, ADB processed an MFF and the first tranche for Guangxi Regional Cooperation 
and Integration Investment to support GZAR’s participation in regional cooperation, particularly 
the GMS program.6 The investment program adopted a holistic approach to address the wide 
range of challenges GZAR faces in regional cooperation. The project was also intended to serve 
as a model for designing future investment projects in other border provinces participating in the 
RCI programs. At the National Consultation and Knowledge Sharing Workshop on Regional 
Cooperation and Integration, jointly organized by ADB and the PRC government on 25–26 May 
2017 in IMAR, representatives of IMAR, XUAR, and Yunnan expressed strong interest in GZAR’s 
experience in designing and implementing RCI projects.  
 
5.   Problems and Opportunities. Like GZAR, IMAR, XUAR, and Yunnan also face a series 
of constraints in implementing RCI programs, particularly in developing border areas and cross-
border economic corridors. Main constraints include: (i) poor infrastructure for connectivity, 
especially at key border crossing points which serve as the main conduit for cross-border 
movement of goods and people; (ii) lack of well-developed industrial parks or border economic 
zones to serve as engines for local economic development by attracting investment and fostering 
enterprise clusters; (iii) low-level urban infrastructure (such as water supply, sewage and waste 
treatment, and power and heating) in border towns which are often key nodes in cross-border 
economic corridors; (iv) poor social infrastructure (especially schools and hospitals) to meet the 
rising demand from across the borders for educational and health services; (v) low level of 
simplification and harmonization of border clearance procedures, especially those related to 
customs inspection and sanitary and phytosanitary services; and (vi) low level of private sector 
participation in cross-border trade and investment activities.  
 
6.   The Government of the PRC has requested ADB’s assistance to IMAR, XUAR, and 
Yunnan to strengthen their participation in the RCI programs. The values ADB is expected to 
contribute include (i) long term financing which is still lacking in those relatively poorer border 
provinces; (ii) RCI knowledge and experience from other parts of the country and rest of Asia, 
including innovative financing modalities for RCI operations; (iii) advice on sharpening RCI 
dimension and maximizing regional benefits of the investment projects; and (iv) opportunities for 
cross-border dialogues and coordinated actions. The list and brief descriptions of the ensuing 
projects to be supported by this transaction TA are in Table 1. The ensuing projects will have high 
positive  RCI  spillovers,  also  benefiting  neighboring  countries  mainly  through  (i)  improved 
connectivity and trade facilitation which will provide better access for neighboring countries to

B.  Outputs and Activities 
7.  The transaction TA will support preparation of the ensuing projects by producing the 
outputs and conducting activities as described in the following:

4 
8.   Output 1: Technical feasibility assessments conducted. The TA will support the 
technical due diligence for project preparation through review of project feasibility study reports 
prepared  by  the  project  executing  and/or  implementing  agencies  to  ensure  the  technical 
soundness of the project design. Special attention will be given to sharpening RCI dimension and 
maximizing regional benefits of the projects and investment programs and the subprojects. Key 
activities will include: (i) reviewing the local feasibility studies in line with the national and 
international best practices; (ii) analyzing baseline situation in the project areas, including the 
projects’ alignment with the local social and economic development plans and relevant RCI 
strategies and action plans; (iii) identifying opportunities to strengthen cross-border synergies; 
and (iv) providing technical support and recommendations to strengthen project design.  
 
9.  Output  2: Investment plan  and  procurement  packages formulated. The TA  will 
support economic, financial, and governance due diligence of the projects and investment 
programs and their subprojects to assess their economic and financial viability. Key activities will 
include: (i) conducting economic and financial analyses; (ii) carrying out financial management 
assessment of the executing and implementing agencies and the project implementing entities, 
and recommending measures where necessary to strengthen their financial management system 
for project implementation; (iii) preparing procurement plan; and (iv) carrying out procurement risk 
assessments of the executing and implementing agencies.  
 
10.  Output 3: Safeguard due diligence completed. The TA will support the safeguard due 
diligence of the projects and subprojects, covering environment, resettlement, and indigenous 
peoples  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement.  The  TA  will  also  support 
assessment of poverty, gender, and other social development issues related to the projects. Key 
activities  will  include  preparing:  (i)  environmental  assessment  and  review  frameworks, 
environment impact assessments and/or initial environmental examinations; (ii) resettlement 
frameworks  and/or resettlement  plans; (iii)  indigenous  peoples  planning frameworks  and/or 
indigenous peoples plans; (iv) stakeholder analysis, participation plan, and conduct stakeholder 
workshops; (v) social, gender, and poverty assessments and action plans if necessary; and (vi) 
assessment of the situation of migrant workers across borders, related to wages, skills training 
needs, employment opportunities, and access to social services in the border towns. 
 
11.  Output 4: Sector assessments prepared. The TA will support preparation of sector 
assessments on industry and trade, water and other urban infrastructure and services, and other 
sectors if necessary. The TA will also support studies and analyses which will lead to preparation 
of road maps and policy frameworks as required for MFF.  
 
12.   Output  5:  Project  management  capacity  of  the  executing  and  implementing 
agencies improved. The TA will strengthen the capacity of the executing and implementing 
agencies and project implementing entities for project preparation and implementation. This 
output will also help improve project readiness to ensure earliest possible implementation. Key 
activities will include: (i) assessing the institutional set up and capacities of the executing and 
implementing agencies and project implementing entities with regard to project preparation and 
implementation, and identifying capacity gaps; (ii) preparing an institutional development and 
capacity building plan to address the capacity needs and enhance inter-agency cooperation and 
coordination;  and  (iii)  organizing  training  on  project  management  (covering  safeguards, 
procurement,  financial  management,  etc.)  and  regional  cooperation  (such  as  trade  and 
investment facilitation, and economic corridor development).

C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA facility is estimated to cost $1.3 million, of which $1 million will be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF–other  sources).  The  key 
expenditure  items  are  listed  in  Appendix  1.7 The  PRC  central  government  and  the  local 
governments in IMAR, XUAR, and Yunnan will provide $0.3 million equivalent of counterpart 
support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, office supplies, secretarial assistance, local 
transportation, provision of relevant government data and reports for the TA consultants’ use, and 
other in-kind contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TA does not 
commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  ADB will administer the TA. East Asia Department’s Public Management, Financial Sector, 
and Regional Cooperation Division (EAPF) will lead the TA implementation in close coordination 
with the Urban and Social Sectors Division (EASS). EAPF will select, administer, and evaluate 
consultants for preparing projects in IMAR and XUAR, and EASS will do the same for preparing 
the  project  in  Yunnan.  The  Ministry  of  Finance  and  National  Development  and  Reform 
Commission  of  the  PRC  will  be  the  executing  agencies,  taking  overall  responsibility  for 
coordinating project preparation. The governments of IMAR, XUAR, and Yunnan will provide 
support  to  EAPF  and  EASS  in  project  preparation.  The  implementation  arrangements  are 
summarized in Table 2. The TA activities for an ensuing project will start only after the project 
concept paper on such ensuing project is approved by ADB.

resources will be required to process Project 2 and Project 3. The project team will apply for additional funding from

6 
15.  Consulting services. The TA will engage international and national consultants for a total 
of 74.75 person-months for preparation of the three ensuing projects in IMAR, XUAR, and Yunnan 
(Appendix 2). The consultants will undertake work in the areas of environment and social 
safeguards, economic and financial analyses, financial management assessment, procurement 
packaging  and  procurement  risk  assessment,  regional  cooperation/trade  facilitation,  civil 
engineering, urban development, water and sanitation, transport, education, health, small- and 
medium-sized  enterprise  development,  customs  and  single  window  development,  logistics 
development,  and  institutional  development  and  capacity  building.  Due  to  the  nature  and 
complexity of the different projects, each project team will determine the most efficient approach 
to carry out the consulting services, either to engage a firm or individual consultants. The 
executing and implementing agencies of the ensuing projects are expected to exercise strong 
ownership in implementing the TA, with full support of the ADB project team members and 
consultants.  Procurement, including consulting services, will follow ADB’s Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, 
as amended from time to time).8 Lump-sum or output-based contracts will be considered for 
consulting services wherever possible in line with ADB’s Midterm Review of Strategy 2020 Action 
Plan (actions 2.9.2 and 2.10.2) to reduce administrative burden and improve the economy, 
efficiency, and value for money.9 The TA proceeds will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
E.  Governance 
 
16.  Financial  management  assessments  to  be  conducted  under  the  TA  will  review  the 
financial  management  systems  of  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  and  project 
implementing  entities,  covering  such  aspects  as  accounting  and  internal  control.  Where 
necessary, financial management action plans will be prepared for the agencies concerned to 
improve their management systems and financial health. Procurement risk assessment will 
identify capacity gaps of the executing and implementing agencies, and recommend measures 
for improvement. Risk assessment and management will identify risks in all key areas of project 
management and implementation and recommend concrete mitigation measures.  
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $ 1,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the People’s Republic of China for Preparing Regional Cooperation and Integration Projects, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.
